rsbNotes.title: Acts 21:37
rsbNotes.text: 21:37 Do you know Greek. The tribune was surprised to hear Paul speak Greek; he had thought him to be an insurrectionist Jew from Egypt, who three years before had appeared there claiming to be a prophet (Josephus, Jewish War 2.261–263).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 21:38
rsbNotes.text: 21:38 Assassins. Lit. “dagger men,” militant Jewish nationalists.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 21:40
rsbNotes.text:
21:40 on the steps. Probably the stairs leading from the temple area to the Antonian Fortress (rebuilt by Herod the Great and named after Mark Antony) on the north edge of the temple platform.

Hebrew language. That is, Aramaic, as commonly spoken by Jews in Palestine, although the priests and Levites would also have known Hebrew. Greek was the common language of the Roman and Mediterranean world.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 22:3
rsbNotes.text: 22:3 Tarsus. An important city, located in Cilicia on the eastern Mediterranean coast north of Cyprus. It was a noted intellectual center.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 22:12
rsbNotes.text: 22:12 Ananias. An appropriate person to meet Saul, who was a zealous Pharisee, “a Hebrew of Hebrews” (Phil. 3:5, 6). Being known to Ananias would recommend Paul to other Jews in the city who would otherwise be suspicious of him (9:10–19).

rsbNotes.title: Acts 22:16
rsbNotes.text: 22:16 be baptized. Baptism in the New Testament is an outward sign of an inward cleansing. As such, it parallels circumcision in the Old Testament (Deut. 10:16; 30:6; Ezek. 44:7).
